title: How are the relations between Japan and China? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot of Chinese people think China and Japan are similar. Granted, I felt this way too, before really understanding Japan. However, I would now dare so far as to argue that China actually has more in common with America than with Japan. Both China and America are multiethnic and multicultural states. Diversity is celebrated in both countries, and both countries practice some form of affirmative action when it comes to minorities (as in, allegedly, it is easier for minorities in both China and America to get into colleges). Japan, however, is a monoethnic state that emphasizes on doing everything the Japanese way. The only ethnic minorities are the Ainu, whom I believe were not even officially recognized as a minority group until about ten years ago.Both China and America place heavy emphasis on individuality over conformity. In China and America, speaking your mind is very important, and you frequently see employees talk back to their bosses, waiters talking back to customers, etc. A lot of Mainland Chinese schools do not even wear uniforms, for that matter, just like in America. People who go to work (salarymen) in America and China tend to wear business casual, or whatevery they want. In Japan, conformity is very much stressed. People are not expected to stand out. In fact, the weird for “weird” (変 or 変わっている) means “to be different”. Calling a Japanese person, “normal” (普通）is a very big compliment. And if you go to Tokyo, you will realize that all of the adult males wear full suit and tie 24/7.Noise is an integral part of life in both America China. In Chinese, being “loud and noisy” (熱鬧) is a part of life. Both Americans and Chinese are known for talking in extremely loud volumes in public places. On the other hand, in Japan, being quiet is very important as to not bother other people. Even on trains, you are not supposed to answer the phone.Both Chinese and Americans care greatly for the cleanliness of their own homes, but neither could care less about the public cleanliness. If you go to Chinese and American cities, you will notice both are very dirty with trash everywhere. Chinese cities fare slightly better than American cities, because they have armies of blue collar workers who are always cleaning the sidewalks. However, Chinese cities are far closer to American cities in terms of dirtiness. In Japan, despite the fact that trash cans are very rare publicly, Japanese almost never litter.Neither Chinese or Americans tend to place a lot of emphasis on traditions, while the Japanese are heavily invested in tradition. China had the cultural revolution, but that isn’t so surprising. Every time a dynasty ends in China, the new dynasty will destroy all traces and culture of the previous dynasty. America doesn’t place a lot of emphasis on tradition because it’s a fairly young country full of immigrants, so it doesn’t have that much tradition to begin with. Japan, on the other hand, is full of traditions. Even today, Japanese people sit on tatami floors, wear yukata, etc.Both China and America have their own definitions of greatness. China’s definition of “greatness” is to be the big brother of East Asia, hiding under the guise of liberating its Asian neighbors from American influence. America’s definition of “greatness” is to be the big brother of the whole world under the guise of spreading freedom and democracy everywhere. Japan, on the other hand, is content being Japan.Of course, I should emphasis that my post contains generalization, but I really do believe that China is more similar to America than it is to Japan. Despite being right next to China, Japan couldn’t possibly be a more different country.
